answers.text: alternating wave crests and valleys that appear as dark and light bands of ice on glacier surfaces

qas.question: What does the width of one dark and one light band measure?

answers.text: when ice from an icefall is severely broken up, increasing ablation surface area during summer

qas.question: Under what conditions are ogives called wave or band ogives?

answers.text: consist only of undulations or color bands

qas.question: what is the term for crests of ice on the glaciers surface?
What is formed when an icefall is covered up?
What do ogives prevent from accumulating?
What is made of both undulations and color bands?

context: <b4_0>Ogives<b4_0/> are <a0_0>alternating wave crests and valleys that appear as dark and light bands of ice on glacier surfaces<a0_0/>. They are linked to seasonal motion of glaciers; the width of one dark and one light band generally equals the <a1_0>annual movement of the glacier<a1_0/>. <b5_0>Ogives<b5_0/> are formed <a2_0>when ice from an icefall is severely broken up, increasing ablation surface area during summer<a2_0/>. This creates a swale and space for <b6_0>snow<b6_0/> accumulation in the winter, which in turn creates a ridge. Sometimes <b7_0>ogives<b7_0/> <a3_0>consist only of undulations or color bands<a3_0/> and are described as wave ogives or band ogives.
